The lack of archaeological proof for it does not diminish its *meaning* for Jewish tradition; it only challenges a literalist historical reading. Many religious individuals find that archaeology, rather than “destroying” faith, **deepens their understanding** by providing context: seeing the altars at Tel Arad or the tunnel of Siloam can make the biblical narratives more tangible and real, even if sometimes in ways that prompt reinterpretation.

Scholars strive to maintain a **neutral, scholarly tone** in presenting findings: we say “the evidence suggests X” rather than “the Bible is wrong about Y.” We also differentiate between **theological claims** (which are not testable by archaeology) and **historical claims** (which are). For instance, the Bible’s assertion that God promised the land to Abraham’s descendants is a theological claim – archaeology cannot prove or disprove a divine promise. But whether “Abraham’s descendants” historically conquered that land in Joshua’s time is a historical claim – one we can investigate and debate with evidence. We make it clear that in highlighting contradictions or lack of evidence, we are not making a value judgment on the Bible’s spiritual messages or the beliefs of faith communities. Instead, we aim to construct a historical narrative consistent with empirical data. In doing so, we **respect the Bible as a rich ancient source** – indeed, one of the most valuable sources we have – but treat it analytically, comparing it with other sources. This approach has been called “**honest history**”: neither cynical dismissal nor apologetic harmonization, but a transparent weighing of all sources.

It’s also essential to recognize the **multivocality of history in this land**. The ancient Israelites/Judahites are one part of the tapestry; Canaanites, Philistines, Moabites, Ammonites, Arameans, and others were also present and have living cultural legacies (for instance, through modern Arab peoples who claim descent from various ancient groups). A balanced treatment does not give exclusive weight to the biblical perspective. For example, while the Bible demonizes Canaanites, archaeology reveals them as simply the preceding culture from which Israel emerged – in many ways, Israel was a *continuation* of Canaan under a new name【11†L969-L977】【11†L971-L979】. Such insights can actually foster *intercultural understanding*, by showing shared heritage. Moreover, by acknowledging, say, that the Jerusalem of David was likely a small stronghold, we potentially defuse absolutist claims that lean on a maximalist reading (and likewise, acknowledging a historical Israel in Canaan refutes extremist denials). 

In summary, our examination takes care to **separate theological affirmation from historical inquiry**. We present what archaeology shows about Israel’s origins while noting that the religious significance of these narratives endures independent of empirical proof or disproof. The Bible can be appreciated as literature and theology, even by those who accept that not every story is literally factual. This position allows scholarly dialogue to proceed without disparaging anyone’s faith. Indeed, as new finds emerge, both scholars and faith communities often adapt and find new layers of meaning. The conversation between archaeology and biblical interpretation is ongoing and can be mutually enriching – as long as we remain clear about which questions each is equipped to answer.

## 6. Conclusion

Archaeology and the biblical texts offer two lenses on the origins and early history of the Jewish people – lenses that are sometimes in focus together, and other times present divergent images. As we have seen, the relationship between the material evidence and the Bible is **complex and continually evolving**. In some instances, they converge strikingly: an ancient stele or ostracon will illuminate a figure or event only briefly alluded to in Scripture, lending historical depth to the narrative. In other cases, decades of excavations have failed to uncover evidence for iconic biblical events, forcing a re-evaluation of how those stories arose and what they mean. This interplay has transformed our understanding of ancient Israel from one based largely on texts to one informed by pottery shards, city walls, animal bones, and inscriptions – a more **three-dimensional picture** of Israel’s emergence in its ancient Near Eastern context.

A balanced overview finds that the **biblical narrative contains both historical memories and later ideological constructs**. The archaeological record robustly attests to an Israelite presence in the highlands by ~1200 BCE【12†L988-L996】【12†L992-L999】, confirming Israel as one of many new peoples to appear as the Bronze Age world crumbled. It further shows that by the 9th century BCE, Israel had formed a kingdom of some stature (the “House of Omri”), and Judah, the “House of David,” was on the historical stage【45†L201-L209】【45†L207-L214】. These are significant corroborations: they anchor key components of the Bible (the existence of a Davidic line, the division into Israel and Judah, the names of kings and foreign wars) in the realm of verifiable history. At the same time, the silence or discrepancies we explored suggest that the biblical authors were **not simply reporting history but writing theological-national epics**, often retrojecting later realities into the past. The Patriarchal age and the Exodus-Conquest sequence, in particular, read today as **foundational mythology** framed in the idiom of history. The archaeological voids around those stories do not diminish their cultural importance, but they do mean historians must place Israel’s emergence in a different light: not as a single generation’s saga of miraculous conquest, but as a centuries-long process of ethnogenesis within Canaan’s hill country【11†L957-L966】【11†L969-L977】. 

That process – the **emergence of Israel** – is significant not only for Jewish history, but for the world. From a small coalition of tribes and villages arose a people whose religious ideas (ethical monotheism) would profoundly influence Western civilization. Archaeologically, Israel’s story is also the story of the highland villagers who built terraced farms, avoided pork, and eventually developed towns and writing – a case study in how a new identity can form out of an older cultural milieu. In the broader ancient Near East, the rise of Israel and Judah filled the vacuum left by Egypt’s retreat and the collapse of Canaanite city-states【11†L913-L922】【11†L919-L924】. These kingdoms, though modest in size compared to Egypt or Assyria, became the stage for religious developments recorded in the Hebrew Bible. Events like the Assyrian and Babylonian conquests, which archaeology vividly records in destruction layers and exile evidence, also mark the transition of Israel’s stories from oral tradition to written scripture (often compiled in exile, giving a poignant perspective to those writings).

Thus, the relationship between archaeology and the Bible is not one of simple verification or falsification, but of **dialogue**. Each new find – a stele, a jar handle, a dwelling – adds a piece to the puzzle of how the biblical record was formed and what actually transpired. Sometimes the pieces click neatly with the biblical picture; other times they force us to redraw parts of that picture. The continuing debates (like those over chronology or David’s realm) show that this is a dynamic field. As methods improve (Lidar surveys, DNA analysis, etc.), we can expect more surprises. What remains clear is that neither the Bible nor archaeology alone gives the whole story. Only by synthesizing both can we approach a **comprehensive understanding**. And in doing so with scholarly neutrality, we respect the Bible’s profound legacy while adhering to evidence-based history. The result is a richer, if more complex, narrative: one that sees ancient Israel not as isolated or monolithic, but as a player in the tapestry of the ancient Near East – shaped by the collapse of Bronze Age cultures, interacting with neighbors like Moab and Aram, developing unique traditions, and leaving a legacy that far outlasted its kingdoms’ political life.

In conclusion, the quest to compare archaeological evidence with the biblical account underscores both the **promise and limits of historical reconstruction**. We can confidently say Israel *was* a people by 1200 BCE (as Merneptah attests)【12†L988-L996】【12†L992-L999】; we can outline how their settlement pattern grew in the central highlands with distinctive cultural practices【12†L1003-L1009】【12†L1018-L1026】; we can trace the rise of their monarchy and its trials with some accuracy through both excavation and inscription【32†L191-L199】【45†L201-L209】. But we also acknowledge that the biblical narrative’s grand theological arcs – from Patriarchs to Exodus to Conquest – are not straightforward historical accounts, but later reflections encoded in national myth. The true history is both more **prosaic** (found in everyday village life remains) and in another sense more **profound** (revealing how identity and faith can emerge from historical experience and memory). The ongoing discourse between shovel and scripture continues to refine our knowledge, ensuring that our understanding of ancient Israel is ever more grounded in reality, even as we appreciate the enduring power of the biblical saga that has been handed down through the ages.

**Sources Cited:** Merneptah Stele【12†L988-L996】【12†L992-L999】; History of Israelite highlands【12†L1003-L1009】【12†L1018-L1026】; Hazor’s destruction and debates【14†L73-L81】【14†L83-L90】; Lachish destruction【17†L153-L157】; Megiddo strata and Egyptian withdrawal【19†L465-L473】; Emergence of Israel from Canaanites【11†L957-L966】【11†L969-L977】; Amarna letters (Canaanite context)【11†L889-L897】【11†L892-L899】; Shasu and Yahweh reference【11†L900-L907】; Mesha Stele description【45†L179-L187】【45†L201-L209】; Tel Dan Stele reference【46†L11-L18】; Documentary Hypothesis context【32†L167-L175】【32†L169-L177】; Linguistic dating and Song of Deborah【28†L261-L268】【28†L269-L277】; Flood narrative parallels【30†L39-L47】【30†L99-L107】; Jericho archaeology vs. Joshua【24†L73-L81】【24†L75-L83】; Minimalist/maximalist positions defined【34†L123-L131】【34†L133-L141】; Convergence methodology【37†L58-L66】; Finkelstein’s low chronology shift【41†L443-L451】【41†L445-L454】; Finkelstein on United Monarchy as later ideology【41†L469-L478】【41†L475-L484】; Politics of archaeology in Israel【43†L171-L179】【43†L259-L267】; Emek Shaveh perspective【43†L253-L262】; The Bible Unearthed on Iron Age origins【32†L191-L199】; Modern scholarly consensus on Exodus/Conquest as later literary saga【24†L73-L81】【24†L75-L83】.

metadata.text: The earliest extra-biblical reference to Israel appears on the Merneptah Stele , an  581 inscription dated to c. 1208 BCE. It records Israel among Pharaoh   655's military victories in Canaan, stating, "Israel is laid waste, his seed is not." A hieroglyphic marker classifies Israel as a semi-nomadic or rural people, distinguishing it from the fortified cities also listed in the inscription. The inclusion of Israel among notable defeated enemies suggests that the group was already an entity of significance in Canaan by the late 13th century BCE.[ 40 ]

metadata.title: History of ancient Israel and Judah - Wikipedia
metadata.text: Around 1200 BCE, the entire Eastern Mediterranean  was impacted by the  124, a period of widespread upheaval marked by population movements, invasions, urban destruction, and the fall of major powers, including the Mycenaean kingdoms , the  634, and Egypt's New Kingdom.[ 23 ] Scholars attribute these disruptions to war, famine, plague, climate change, invasions, or a combination of factors.[ 23 ] Canaan was affected too,[ 24 ] its large cities were devastated, setting the stage for a new era in the region's history. The process was gradual,[ 25 ] and a strong Egyptian presence continued into the 12th century BCE, and, while some Canaanite cities were destroyed, others continued to exist in Iron Age I.[ 26 ]

metadata.title: History of ancient Israel and Judah - Wikipedia
metadata.text: Canaan was affected too,[ 24 ] its large cities were devastated, setting the stage for a new era in the region's history. The process was gradual,[ 25 ] and a strong Egyptian presence continued into the 12th century BCE, and, while some Canaanite cities were destroyed, others continued to exist in Iron Age I.[ 26 ] It is in this later part of the Late Bronze Age that a people called Israel are first attested.[ 27 ]

metadata.text: The Egyptians could be responsible. Pharaoh Seti I, in an inscription describing his military campaign against Canaan ca. 1300 B.C., claimed to have destroyed Hazor. Another possibility is that Ramses II could have conquered the city, either on his way northward to Syria before the Battle of Kadesh in 1275 B.C. or on his return to Egypt afterward. Yet Ben-Tor believes that the intentional smashing of statues at Hazor, particularly those of the Egyptian kings, makes these possibilities unlikely. He also dismisses the likelihood of destruction at the hands of a rival Canaanite city-state because of the apparent absence of nearby cities powerful enough to attack Hazor. metadata.title: Tel Megiddo - Wikipedia
metadata.text: Iron Age I (c. 1150–950 BCE) began in Tel Megiddo around 1150 BCE.[ 28 ] Egypt's control of this Canaanite region ended around 1130 BCE,[ 29 ] as Stratum VIIA was destroyed around this date or shortly thereafter,[ 30 ] attested in the palace and adjacent Level H-11 building.[ 31 ] A Canaanite dynasty still controlled the city after the Egyptians abandoned the region.[ 32 ] The beginning of Philistine Bichrome pottery at Megiddo was after 1124 BCE, or in the period (c. 1128–1079 BCE), based on radiocarbon datings with a confidence of 95.4%.[ 27 ]

metadata.title: History of ancient Israel and Judah - Wikipedia
metadata.text: By the 13th–12th centuries BCE, new villages appeared in the central hill country, which scholars identify as the earliest Israelite settlements. These villages were typically unwalled and housed only a few hundred people each. These sites exhibit continuity with Late Bronze Age culture, including in most pottery forms,[ 39 ] while also displaying changes: the usage of collared-rim jars, the absence of pig bones (possibly reflecting dietary practices), and the development of four-room house architecture, a feature unique to Israelite settlements.

metadata.title: History of ancient Israel and Judah - Wikipedia
metadata.text: Around this period, substantial settlement is attested archaeologically in the highlands of central Canaan. In the Late Bronze Age there were no more than about 25 villages in the highlands, but this increased to over 300 by the end of Iron Age I, while the settled population doubled from 20,000 to 40,000.[ 41 ] The villages were more numerous and larger in the north, and probably shared the highlands with pastoral nomads, who left no remains.[ 42 ] Archaeologists and historians attempting to trace the origins of these villagers have found it impossible to identify any distinctive features that could define them as specifically Israelite – collared-rim jars and four-room houses have been

metadata.title: History of ancient Israel and Judah - Wikipedia
metadata.text: population. During this period, Israelites lived primarily in small villages, the largest of which had populations of up to 300 or 400.[ 46 ][ 47 ] Their villages were built on hilltops. Their houses were built in clusters around a common courtyard. They built three- or four-room houses out of mudbrick with a stone foundation and sometimes with a second story made of wood. The inhabitants lived by farming and herding. They built terraces to farm on hillsides, planting various crops and maintaining orchards. The villages were largely economically self-sufficient and economic interchange was prevalent. According to the Bible, prior to the rise of the Israelite monarchy the early Israelites were led by the Biblical judges, or chieftains who served as military

metadata.title: History of ancient Israel and Judah - Wikipedia
metadata.text: leaders in times of crisis. Scholars are divided over the historicity of this account. However, it is likely that regional chiefdoms and polities provided security. The small villages were unwalled but were likely subjects of the major town in the area. Writing was known and available for recording, even at small sites.[ 48 ][ 49 ][ 50 ][ 51 ][ 52 ]

metadata.text: While biblical texts often portray Israel as opponents of the Canaanites, much of Israel's heritage was deeply Canaanite in character—culturally, linguistically, and religiously. Some of the Bible's earliest compositions, such as the Song of the Sea  and the  650, seem to have Canaanite roots.[ 37 ] The Hebrew language is referred to in the Book of Isaiah  as the "lip of Canaan",[ 38 ] and was closely related to neighboring dialects like  652 and Moabite .[ 37 ] Alongside material continuity with Late Bronze Age Canaan[ 39 ]—albeit with some distinctive developments—the early Israelite religion also mirrored  654.[ 37 ]

metadata.text: Modern scholarship generally views ancient Israel's origins as emerging primarily from the indigenous population of Canaan.[ 31 ][ 32 ] According to this view, the early Israelites likely consisted of diverse elements drawn from Late Bronze Age society, including rural villagers, former settled peoples, displaced peasants, and pastoralist groups.[ 33 ][ 31 ] These were joined by marginal segments of society, such as the 'Apiru  and  123, who lived on the fringes of settled areas.[ 33 ][ 31 ][ a ] Additional external elements may have included fugitive or runaway Semitic slaves from Egypt, who likely constituted at least part of the emerging Israelite population.[ 31 ][ 35 ][ 36 ] It is documented that various Semitic peoples lived in Egypt at

metadata.title: Mesha Stele - Wikipedia
metadata.text: The Mesha Stele, also known as the Moabite Stone, is a stele  dated around 840 BCE containing a significant  86 in the name of King Mesha  of  88 (a kingdom located in modern Jordan ). Mesha tells how  90, the god of Moab, had been angry with his people and had allowed them to be subjugated to the Kingdom of Israel , but at length, Chemosh returned and assisted Mesha to throw off the yoke of Israel and restore the lands of Moab. Mesha also describes his many building projects.[ 1 ] It is written in a variant of the  92, closely related to the Paleo-Hebrew script.[ 2 ][ 3 ]

metadata.title: The Politics of Archeology in Israel | My Jewish Learning
metadata.text: Most recent and perhaps most controversial is the potential discovery of David’s palace. For many years, traditional archeologists puzzled over the absence of a palace, within the fortified boundaries of the ancient city, befitting the royal King David. Archeologist Dr. Eilat Mazar went in search of a large residence impressive enough to match the palace described in the Bible.

metadata.title: The Politics of Archeology in Israel | My Jewish Learning
metadata.text: writes that David went down to the fortress when an enemy approached, suggesting that his palace was unfortified. While excavating in 2005, Mazar found the walls of a very large structure as well as a tower, on the high ground north of the fortress, which may suggest that the Bible was as accurate as a map and that David lived in regal luxury.

metadata.title: The Politics of Archeology in Israel | My Jewish Learning
metadata.text: The naysayers, with Finkelstein at the helm, question the early dating of the find. Perhaps, the critique goes, the enthusiasm to prove King David’s importance and validate the Bible led Mazar to misdate the findings. The dating of building foundations throughout Israel isn’t extremely precise and is constantly being debated and revised. While archaeological finds of letters and stamps throughout Israel incontrovertibly prove the existence of a “house of David,” whether or not this structure was a palace belonging to David–king of the united Israel–is open to interpretation.

Archeologists also found 8th century additions to the tunnels, attributed to King Hezekiah’s attempt to divert the city’s water source to protect it from the Assyrian enemy, as described in the Bible (II Chronicles ch. 32:2-4).

metadata.title: The Politics of Archeology in Israel | My Jewish Learning
metadata.text: The Ir David Foundation, under the leadership of David Be’eri, says that they have discovered the place “where it all began.” On a tour of the ever-growing archeological dig in the area, one can see many impressive finds: clay seals documenting the names of two ministers to King Zedekiah, mentioned in the Book of Jeremiah (c. 6th century BCE); a huge pool which may have served as a mikveh (ritual bath) for pilgrims during the Second Temple period and perhaps during the First Temple period; and a wide avenue of steps leading through the city toward the Temple. The archeological park also screens a reenactment film of David’s capturing of the city.

metadata.text: There are only a handful of non-cuneiform references to Gilgamesh. The Flood narrative from the Gilgamesh Epic remains the most overt connection between the Hebrew Bible and the Mesopotamian epic narrative, some hundred years after it was first noted by George Smith. The Flood narrative within the biblical text is not, however, the only point of contact between the two works of ancient literature. The name of the heroic protagonist of the Gilgamesh Epic may be found in a text from the Dead Sea Scrolls known as The Book of Giants.

metadata.title: The Influence of Gilgamesh on the Bible | Bible Interp
metadata.text: From the very inception of the study of the Gilgamesh Epic when George Smith first observed parallels with the biblical Flood, Gilgamesh has been contrasted and companioned with the Bible. In the prologue to his famous comparison of ancient Flood narratives, Heidel observed that the narratives of the Flood form the most overt parallels between the Hebrew Bible and the Gilgamesh Epic. Heidel stated that the Flood stories provide “the most remarkable parallels between the Old Testament and the entire corpus of cuneiform inscriptions from Mesopotamia” (Heidel 1946, 224).

metadata.title: Biblical maximalism - Wikipedia
metadata.text: The debate between the two parties revolves, predominantly, around one major issue in the sphere of biblical interpretation: the existence, or nonexistence, of the united kingdom of Solomon  and  48.[ 2 ] Minimalists argue that this kingdom must have been different from the one presented in the biblical texts—1 Kings  and  50, for example—stating that the current archaeological evidence does not indicate that a state organization of the kind once existed. Maximalists, on the other hand, hold that the archeological evidence currently uncovered is sufficient to prove the existence of the United Monarchy.[ 4 ]

metadata.title: Pondering the Spade: Discussing Important Convergences between Archaeology and Old Testament Studies - Verbum
metadata.text: underappreciated or ignored. Using William Dever’s idea of convergence, this work attempts to flesh out details on how archaeology and Old Testament studies merge. It examines some of the most important archaeological finds to date and determines that, whether through a broad or narrow convergence, the history of research has shown that these two separate disciplines exhibit a tendency to inform one another. In the case of Old Testament studies, these convergences may even be paradigm-shifting. In every case, the convergences are historically and culturally informative, and therefore illuminate the depth of the biblical text.

In the case of Old Testament studies, these convergences may even be paradigm-shifting. In every case, the convergences are historically and culturally informative, and therefore illuminate the depth of the biblical text.

In a later verse (10:13), the narrative notes the uniqueness of these events: "None of the cities that stood on mounds did Israel burn, except Hazor only; that Joshua burned." The destruction, Yadin wrote in Hazor: The Rediscovery of a Great Citadel of the Bible (1975), "is doubtless to be ascribed to the Israelite tribes, as related in the Book of Joshua." Critics argue that the biblical account is a mythic saga written centuries after the events it describes. Various scholars have suggested that the destruction was the work of the Egyptians, rival Canaanite city-states, or the Sea Peoples from the Aegean, who were marauding along the eastern Mediterranean coast at about this time.

metadata.text: Finkelstein sees the biblical description of the time of David and Solomon as multilayered. He acknowledges the historicity of the founders of the Davidic Dynasty, places them in the 10th century BCE, and considers the possibility that the description of the rise of David to power conceals old memories of his activity as a leader of an Apiru-band that was active in the southern fringe of Judah. Yet, he sees the description of a great United Monarchy as an ideological construct that represents the ideology of late-monarchic author/s in the late 7th century BCE, first and foremost the pan-Israelite ideology of the days of King Josiah of Judah. metadata.title: Israel Finkelstein - Wikipedia
metadata.text: Until the 1990s, the chronology of the Iron Age in the Levant had been anchored in the biblical account of the great United Monarchy of David and Solomon. Accordingly, the Iron I ended ca. 1000 BCE and the Iron IIA was dated from 1000 BCE until the campaign of Pharaoh Sheshonq I (biblical Shishak) ca. 925 BCE. The two Iron IIA palaces at Megiddo were conceived as the material manifestation for the Solomonic Empire.[ 11 ] While preparing for the excavations at Megiddo in the early 1990s, Finkelstein noticed difficulties in this scheme. metadata.text: While biblical texts often portray Israel as opponents of the Canaanites, much of Israel's heritage was deeply Canaanite in character—culturally, linguistically, and religiously. Some of the Bible's earliest compositions, such as the Song of the Sea  and the  650, seem to have Canaanite roots.[ 37 ] The Hebrew language is referred to in the Book of Isaiah  as the "lip of Canaan",[ 38 ] and was closely related to neighboring dialects like  652 and Moabite.[ 37 ] Alongside material continuity with Late Bronze Age Canaan[ 39 ]—albeit with some distinctive developments—the early Israelite religion also mirrored  654 typical Canaanite

metadata.title: History of ancient Israel and Judah - Wikipedia
metadata.text: ImageThe Merneptah Stele  (c. 1208 BCE) – an Egyptian inscription by Pharaoh  655 – contains the earliest known reference to "Israel", indicating a people in Canaan at that time

metadata.title: History of ancient Israel and Judah - Wikipedia
metadata.text: The earliest extra-biblical reference to Israel appears on the Merneptah Stele , an  581 inscription dated to c. 1208 BCE. It records Israel among Pharaoh   655's military victories in Canaan, stating, "Israel is laid waste, his seed is not." A hieroglyphic marker classifies Israel as a semi-nomadic or rural people, distinguishing it from the fortified cities also listed in the inscription. The inclusion of Israel among notable defeated enemies suggests that the group was already an entity of significance in Canaan by the late 13th century BCE.[ 40 ]

metadata.text: Modern scholarship generally views ancient Israel's origins as emerging primarily from the indigenous population of Canaan.[ 31 ][ 32 ] According to this view, the early Israelites likely consisted of diverse elements drawn from Late Bronze Age society, including rural villagers, former settled peoples, displaced peasants, and pastoralist groups.[ 33 ][ 31 ] These were joined by marginal segments of society, such as the 'Apiru  and  123, who lived on the fringes of settled areas.[ 33 ][ 31 ][ a ] Additional external elements may have included fugitive or runaway Semitic slaves from Egypt, who likely constituted at least part of the emerging Israelite population.[ 31 ][ 35 ][ 36 ] It is documented that various Semitic peoples lived in Egypt at

metadata.text: Around 1200 BCE, the entire Eastern Mediterranean  was impacted by the  124, a period of widespread upheaval marked by population movements, invasions, urban destruction, and the fall of major powers, including the Mycenaean kingdoms , the  634, and Egypt's New Kingdom.[ 23 ] Scholars attribute these disruptions to war, famine, plague, climate change, invasions, or a combination of factors.[ 23 ] Canaan was affected too,[ 24 ] its large cities were devastated, setting the stage for a new era in the region's history. The process was gradual,[ 25 ] and a strong Egyptian presence continued into the 12th century BCE, and, while some Canaanite cities were destroyed, others continued to exist in Iron Age I.[ 26 ]

metadata.title: History of ancient Israel and Judah - Wikipedia
metadata.text: Canaan was affected too,[ 24 ] its large cities were devastated, setting the stage for a new era in the region's history. The process was gradual,[ 25 ] and a strong Egyptian presence continued into the 12th century BCE, and, while some Canaanite cities were destroyed, others continued to exist in Iron Age I.[ 26 ] It is in this later part of the Late Bronze Age that a people called Israel are first attested.[ 27 ]

metadata.text: By the 13th–12th centuries BCE, new villages appeared in the central hill country, which scholars identify as the earliest Israelite settlements. These villages were typically unwalled and housed only a few hundred people each. These sites exhibit continuity with Late Bronze Age culture, including in most pottery forms,[ 39 ] while also displaying changes: the usage of collared-rim jars, the absence of pig bones (possibly reflecting dietary practices), and the development of four-room house architecture, a feature unique to Israelite

metadata.text: that time and took Hazor and smote its king with the sword, for Hazor formerly was the head of all those kingdoms. And he put to the sword all who were in it, utterly destroying them; there was none left that breathed, and he burned Hazor with fire" (Joshua 11:10-11). In a later verse (10:13), the narrative notes the uniqueness of these events: "None of the cities that stood on mounds did Israel burn, except Hazor only; that Joshua burned." The destruction, Yadin wrote in Hazor: The Rediscovery of a Great Citadel of the Bible (1975), "is doubtless to be ascribed to the Israelite tribes, as related in the Book of Joshua." metadata.title: Tel Megiddo - Wikipedia
metadata.text: Iron Age I (c. 1150–950 BCE) began in Tel Megiddo around 1150 BCE.[ 28 ] Egypt's control of this Canaanite region ended around 1130 BCE,[ 29 ] as Stratum VIIA was destroyed around this date or shortly thereafter,[ 30 ] attested in the palace and adjacent Level H-11 building.[ 31 ] A Canaanite dynasty still controlled the city after the Egyptians abandoned the region.[ 32 ] The beginning of Philistine Bichrome pottery at Megiddo was after 1124 BCE, or in the period (c. 1128–1079 BCE), based on radiocarbon datings with a confidence of 95.4%.[ 27 ]

metadata.title: Composing the Song of Deborah: Empirical Models
metadata.text: Most modern scholars consider the Song of the Sea and the Song of Deborah among the oldest parts of the Hebrew Bible.[2] The early date for the Song of Deborah is based in large part on matters of language,[3] but certain details mentioned in the song also point in this direction:

metadata.title: Composing the Song of Deborah: Empirical Models
metadata.text: a practice of growing hair long before battle, is found only here and in the ancient poem of Deut 32:42 (מֵרֹאשׁ פַּרְעוֹת אוֹיֵב);[4] * The structure of the tribal system seems to fit the Iron I period rather than anything later: in the absence of a monarchy, Deborah relies on the tribes coming to mutual defense—and then laments their failure to do so; * The economic picture of the poem suggests a lack of any centralized authority or economic system.[5]

metadata.title: The Influence of Gilgamesh on the Bible | Bible Interp
metadata.text: There are only a handful of non-cuneiform references to Gilgamesh. The Flood narrative from the Gilgamesh Epic remains the most overt connection between the Hebrew Bible and the Mesopotamian epic narrative, some hundred years after it was first noted by George Smith. The Flood narrative within the biblical text is not, however, the only point of contact between the two works of ancient literature. The name of the heroic protagonist of the Gilgamesh Epic may be found in a text from the Dead Sea Scrolls known as The Book of Giants.

metadata.title: Biblical maximalism - Wikipedia
metadata.text: and the historical authenticity of ancient Israel as a whole.[ 1 ] Due to differences between the Bible and 19th- and 20th-century archaeological findings, there exist discrepancies between these two parties of biblical exegetists: the biblical maximalists argue that prior to Judaism 's  46 (the period that spanned the 6th-century B.C.), the Bible serves an accurate historical source and should influence the conclusions drawn from archaeological studies; whereas biblical minimalists assert that the Bible must be read as fiction, unless proven otherwise by archaeological findings, and ought not be considered in secular studies.[ 2 ][ 3 ]

metadata.title: Biblical maximalism - Wikipedia
metadata.text: The debate between the two parties revolves, predominantly, around one major issue in the sphere of biblical interpretation: the existence, or nonexistence, of the united kingdom of Solomon  and  48.[ 2 ] Minimalists argue that this kingdom must have been different from the one presented in the biblical texts—1 Kings  and  50, for example—stating that the current archaeological evidence does not indicate that a state organization of the kind once existed. Maximalists, on the other hand, hold that the archeological evidence currently uncovered is sufficient to prove the existence of the United Monarchy.[ 4 ]

metadata.title: Pondering the Spade: Discussing Important Convergences between Archaeology and Old Testament Studies - Verbum
metadata.text: underappreciated or ignored. Using William Dever’s idea of convergence, this work attempts to flesh out details on how archaeology and Old Testament studies merge. It examines some of the most important archaeological finds to date and determines that, whether through a broad or narrow convergence, the history of research has shown that these two separate disciplines exhibit a tendency to inform one another. In the case of Old Testament studies, these convergences may even be paradigm-shifting. In every case, the convergences are historically and culturally informative, and therefore illuminate the depth of the biblical text.

metadata.text: According to Finkelstein's Low Chronology, the Iron Age I lasted until the middle of the 10th century BCE, while the Iron IIA is dated between the middle of the 10th century and ca. 800 BCE, if not slightly later. This means that the Megiddo palaces and other features which had traditionally been attributed to the time of King Solomon – features which date to the late Iron IIA – should indeed be associated with the endeavors of the Omride Dynasty in the first half of the 9th century BCE. metadata.title: Israel Finkelstein - Wikipedia
metadata.text: Finkelstein sees the biblical description of the time of David and Solomon as multilayered. He acknowledges the historicity of the founders of the Davidic Dynasty, places them in the 10th century BCE, and considers the possibility that the description of the rise of David to power conceals old memories of his activity as a leader of an Apiru-band that was active in the southern fringe of Judah. Yet, he sees the description of a great United Monarchy as an ideological construct that represents the ideology of late-monarchic author/s in the late 7th century BCE, first and foremost the pan-Israelite ideology of the days of King Josiah of Judah. According to him, the historical David and Solomon ruled over a small territory in the southern highlands – a territory not very

metadata.title: Israel Finkelstein - Wikipedia
metadata.text: construct that represents the ideology of late-monarchic author/s in the late 7th century BCE, first and foremost the pan-Israelite ideology of the days of King Josiah of Judah. According to him, the historical David and Solomon ruled over a small territory in the southern highlands – a territory not very different from that of Jerusalem of the Late Bronze Age. Finkelstein sees much of the description of King Solomon as representing realities from late monarchic times: First, from the later days of the Northern Kingdom (for instance, the reference to Megiddo, Hazor and Gezer in 1 Kings 9:15 and to the stables, horses and chariots of Solomon). content_references.title: History of ancient Israel and Judah - Wikipedia
content_references.snippet: The earliest extra-biblical reference to Israel appears on the Merneptah Stele , an  581 inscription dated to c. 1208 BCE. It records Israel among Pharaoh   655's military victories in Canaan, stating, "Israel is laid waste, his seed is not." A hieroglyphic marker classifies Israel as a semi-nomadic or rural people, distinguishing it from the fortified cities also listed in the inscription. The inclusion of Israel among notable defeated enemies suggests that the group was already an entity of significance in Canaan by the late 13th century BCE.[ 40 ]

content_references.title: History of ancient Israel and Judah - Wikipedia
content_references.snippet: Around 1200 BCE, the entire Eastern Mediterranean  was impacted by the  124, a period of widespread upheaval marked by population movements, invasions, urban destruction, and the fall of major powers, including the Mycenaean kingdoms , the  634, and Egypt's New Kingdom.[ 23 ] Scholars attribute these disruptions to war, famine, plague, climate change, invasions, or a combination of factors.[ 23 ] Canaan was affected too,[ 24 ] its large cities were devastated, setting the stage for a new era in the region's history. The process was gradual,[ 25 ] and a strong Egyptian presence continued into the 12th century BCE, and, while some Canaanite cities were destroyed, others continued to exist in Iron Age I.[ 26 ]

Yet Ben-Tor believes that the intentional smashing of statues at Hazor, particularly those of the Egyptian kings, makes these possibilities unlikely. He also dismisses the likelihood of destruction at the hands of a rival Canaanite city-state because of the apparent absence of nearby cities powerful enough to attack Hazor. content_references.title: Tel Megiddo - Wikipedia
content_references.snippet: Iron Age I (c. 1150–950 BCE) began in Tel Megiddo around 1150 BCE.[ 28 ] Egypt's control of this Canaanite region ended around 1130 BCE,[ 29 ] as Stratum VIIA was destroyed around this date or shortly thereafter,[ 30 ] attested in the palace and adjacent Level H-11 building.[ 31 ] A Canaanite dynasty still controlled the city after the Egyptians abandoned the region.[ 32 ] The beginning of Philistine Bichrome pottery at Megiddo was after 1124 BCE, or in the period (c. 1128–1079 BCE), based on radiocarbon datings with a confidence of 95.4%.[ 27 ]

content_references.title: History of ancient Israel and Judah - Wikipedia
content_references.snippet: By the 13th–12th centuries BCE, new villages appeared in the central hill country, which scholars identify as the earliest Israelite settlements. These villages were typically unwalled and housed only a few hundred people each. These sites exhibit continuity with Late Bronze Age culture, including in most pottery forms,[ 39 ] while also displaying changes: the usage of collared-rim jars, the absence of pig bones (possibly reflecting dietary practices), and the development of four-room house architecture, a feature unique to Israelite settlements.

content_references.title: History of ancient Israel and Judah - Wikipedia
content_references.snippet: population. During this period, Israelites lived primarily in small villages, the largest of which had populations of up to 300 or 400.[ 46 ][ 47 ] Their villages were built on hilltops. Their houses were built in clusters around a common courtyard. They built three- or four-room houses out of mudbrick with a stone foundation and sometimes with a second story made of wood. The inhabitants lived by farming and herding. They built terraces to farm on hillsides, planting various crops and maintaining orchards. The villages were largely economically self-sufficient and economic interchange was prevalent. According to the Bible, prior to the rise of the Israelite monarchy the early Israelites were led by the Biblical judges, or chieftains who served as military

content_references.title: History of ancient Israel and Judah - Wikipedia
content_references.snippet: leaders in times of crisis. Scholars are divided over the historicity of this account. However, it is likely that regional chiefdoms and polities provided security. The small villages were unwalled but were likely subjects of the major town in the area. Writing was known and available for recording, even at small sites.[ 48 ][ 49 ][ 50 ][ 51 ][ 52 ]

Mesha tells how  90, the god of Moab, had been angry with his people and had allowed them to be subjugated to the Kingdom of Israel , but at length, Chemosh returned and assisted Mesha to throw off the yoke of Israel and restore the lands of Moab. content_references.title: The Politics of Archeology in Israel | My Jewish Learning
content_references.snippet: Most recent and perhaps most controversial is the potential discovery of David’s palace. For many years, traditional archeologists puzzled over the absence of a palace, within the fortified boundaries of the ancient city, befitting the royal King David. Archeologist Dr. Eilat Mazar went in search of a large residence impressive enough to match the palace described in the Bible.

content_references.title: The Politics of Archeology in Israel | My Jewish Learning
content_references.snippet: writes that David went down to the fortress when an enemy approached, suggesting that his palace was unfortified. While excavating in 2005, Mazar found the walls of a very large structure as well as a tower, on the high ground north of the fortress, which may suggest that the Bible was as accurate as a map and that David lived in regal luxury.

content_references.title: The Politics of Archeology in Israel | My Jewish Learning
content_references.snippet: The naysayers, with Finkelstein at the helm, question the early dating of the find. Perhaps, the critique goes, the enthusiasm to prove King David’s importance and validate the Bible led Mazar to misdate the findings. The dating of building foundations throughout Israel isn’t extremely precise and is constantly being debated and revised. While archaeological finds of letters and stamps throughout Israel incontrovertibly prove the existence of a “house of David,” whether or not this structure was a palace belonging to David–king of the united Israel–is open to interpretation.

content_references.title: The Politics of Archeology in Israel | My Jewish Learning
content_references.snippet: The Ir David Foundation, under the leadership of David Be’eri, says that they have discovered the place “where it all began.” On a tour of the ever-growing archeological dig in the area, one can see many impressive finds: clay seals documenting the names of two ministers to King Zedekiah, mentioned in the Book of Jeremiah (c. 6th century BCE); a huge pool which may have served as a mikveh (ritual bath) for pilgrims during the Second Temple period and perhaps during the First Temple period; and a wide avenue of steps leading through the city toward the Temple. The archeological park also screens a reenactment film of David’s capturing of the city.

The Flood narrative within the biblical text is not, however, the only point of contact between the two works of ancient literature. The name of the heroic protagonist of the Gilgamesh Epic may be found in a text from the Dead Sea Scrolls known as The Book of Giants.

content_references.title: The Influence of Gilgamesh on the Bible | Bible Interp
content_references.snippet: From the very inception of the study of the Gilgamesh Epic when George Smith first observed parallels with the biblical Flood, Gilgamesh has been contrasted and companioned with the Bible. In the prologue to his famous comparison of ancient Flood narratives, Heidel observed that the narratives of the Flood form the most overt parallels between the Hebrew Bible and the Gilgamesh Epic. Heidel stated that the Flood stories provide “the most remarkable parallels between the Old Testament and the entire corpus of cuneiform inscriptions from Mesopotamia” (Heidel 1946, 224).

content_references.title: Biblical maximalism - Wikipedia
content_references.snippet: The debate between the two parties revolves, predominantly, around one major issue in the sphere of biblical interpretation: the existence, or nonexistence, of the united kingdom of Solomon  and  48.[ 2 ] Minimalists argue that this kingdom must have been different from the one presented in the biblical texts—1 Kings  and  50, for example—stating that the current archaeological evidence does not indicate that a state organization of the kind once existed. Maximalists, on the other hand, hold that the archeological evidence currently uncovered is sufficient to prove the existence of the United Monarchy.[ 4 ]

content_references.title: Pondering the Spade: Discussing Important Convergences between Archaeology and Old Testament Studies - Verbum
content_references.snippet: underappreciated or ignored. Using William Dever’s idea of convergence, this work attempts to flesh out details on how archaeology and Old Testament studies merge. It examines some of the most important archaeological finds to date and determines that, whether through a broad or narrow convergence, the history of research has shown that these two separate disciplines exhibit a tendency to inform one another. In the case of Old Testament studies, these convergences may even be paradigm-shifting. In every case, the convergences are historically and culturally informative, and therefore illuminate the depth of the biblical text.

content_references.snippet: Around 1200 BCE, the entire Eastern Mediterranean  was impacted by the  124, a period of widespread upheaval marked by population movements, invasions, urban destruction, and the fall of major powers, including the Mycenaean kingdoms , the  634, and Egypt's New Kingdom.[ 23 ] Scholars attribute these disruptions to war, famine, plague, climate change, invasions, or a combination of factors.[ 23 ] Canaan was affected too,[ 24 ] its large cities were devastated, setting the stage for a new era in the region's history. The process was gradual,[ 25 ] and a strong Egyptian presence continued into the 12th century BCE, and, while some Canaanite cities were destroyed, others continued to exist in Iron Age I.[ 26 ]

Maximalists, on the other hand, hold that the archeological evidence currently uncovered is sufficient to prove the existence of the United Monarchy.[ 4 ]

content_references.snippet: underappreciated or ignored. Using William Dever’s idea of convergence, this work attempts to flesh out details on how archaeology and Old Testament studies merge. It examines some of the most important archaeological finds to date and determines that, whether through a broad or narrow convergence, the history of research has shown that these two separate disciplines exhibit a tendency to inform one another. In the case of Old Testament studies, these convergences may even be paradigm-shifting. In every case, the convergences are historically and culturally informative, and therefore illuminate the depth of the biblical text.

content_references.title: Israel Finkelstein - Wikipedia
content_references.snippet: Finkelstein sees the biblical description of the time of David and Solomon as multilayered. He acknowledges the historicity of the founders of the Davidic Dynasty, places them in the 10th century BCE, and considers the possibility that the description of the rise of David to power conceals old memories of his activity as a leader of an Apiru-band that was active in the southern fringe of Judah. Yet, he sees the description of a great United Monarchy as an ideological construct that represents the ideology of late-monarchic author/s in the late 7th century BCE, first and foremost the pan-Israelite ideology of the days of King Josiah of Judah. content_references.title: The Politics of Archeology in Israel | My Jewish Learning
content_references.snippet: The finds from the Second Temple period are relatively uncontested, however much debate now surrounds the beginnings of Jewish rule in Israel and the Davidic Kingdom in Judea. In the past two decades, scholars and activists have accused archeologists of being driven to prove the truth of the Bible when dating and interpreting their finds. Underlying some of these accusations is the insinuation that Zionist archeologists wish to bolster the Jewish right to the land by pushing Jewish political dominance in Israel to an earlier date.
